docs.lead_paragraph: O.K., Not Doin' So Fine It's been a rough week for Rodgers and Hammerstein. Less than a year after the centenary of Richard Rodgers's birth and the attendant hoopla, both of the Broadway revivals of Rodgers and Hammerstein -- ''Oklahoma!'' and ''Flower Drum Song'' -- are taking their lumps.
docs.abstract: On Stage and Off column reports surprising announcement that Oklahoma! revival will close this spring; second revival, Flower Drum Song, is also on uncertain ground; illness plagues previews of Ma Rainey's Black Bottom; The Graduate and Imaginary Friends to close; Cynthia Nixon, whose theater career was interrupted by television fame, will appear in String Fever before shooting final season of Sex and the City; photo; Les Miserables is extended until May 18 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush vowed tonight that he would not burden future generations with the nation's pressing domestic problems: growing budget deficits, a lagging economy and a crisis in health care. He offered few new specifics on how he would solve those problems, and Democrats asserted that some of his proposals could actually worsen them. But Mr. Bush, addressing one of the core critiques of his administration, argued that he ''will not pass along our problems to other Congresses, other presidents and other generations.''

headline.main: President Vows Steps to Handle Domestic Woes
headline.kicker: STATE OF THE UNION: DOMESTIC AGENDA
